YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Second Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [9th December, 1963] to Question [9th December, 1963],

    "That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to: -

    `We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government on the 29th November, 1963.'.". -[The Prime Minister].

    Which Amendment was,

"at end, to add -

    `; but this Assembly regrets that the Government in helping to impose Malaysia on the people has caused great difficulties and hardships to them in Singapore and urges the Government to take immediate steps to persuade the Central Government to get rid of foreign interference, negotiate with the Indonesian Government, and resolve all existing differences to our mutual benefit, and so help to bring stability, peace and prosperity to South-East Asia'. ". -[Mr Chia Thye Poh].

    Mr Speaker: The Question is, "That the words proposed to be added, be there added." As I indicated yesterday, the debate can range over the whole of the Address as well as the amendment. The Member for Bras Basah had the Floor.

2.34 p.m.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Yang di-Pertuan Negara has stated very accurately that our life is now interwoven with that of Malaysia, we cannot be effective, however successful we may be in the Malaysian scene, if we confine ourselves to Singapore. There must be an inter-flow of political ideas and politicians among the territories in Malaysia. Federation politicians have sought to spread their activities and their views in Singapore. It is only proper and indeed desirable that political ideas originating from Singapore should have its impact over the whole of Malaysia. The flow of political ideas and politicians from Singapore has not moved as smoothly

Column: 216

and as quickly as some of us might have hoped. I think I can say for all the politicians in Singapore that their desire to have their views spread over a greater area has been impeded by unnatural forces. It is my hope that this Government will do all it can to convince the seat of authority in Kuala Lumpur that if democracy in this vast area of Malaysia is to survive and prosper, there must be a free flow of political ideas and politicians throughout this territory.

    Everyone knows that democracy depends to a large extent on the existence of a free democratic trade union movement. In Singapore we are fortunate to have a free, virile, democratic and, above all, a patriotic trade union movement. This trade union movement of Singapore has shown and proved itself in the past few years that it can contain and conscribe political adventurers seeking to use the trade union movement for anti-national purposes. With this experience behind it, the trade union movement in Singapore is certainly in a position to assist trade union movements elsewhere in Malaysia in the fight against Communist elements posing as trade unionists.

    All round the trade industrial front in Singapore, the democratic trade Union movement represented by the National Trade Union Congress has made significant progress. It has indeed been, as His Excellency said, a large-scale eradication of industrial discontent and unrest on the basis of industrial peace with justice. The Industrial Relations Ordinance was made law in 1959. In 1960 the Industrial Arbitration Court made its first impact. Nevertheless, experience over the years has shown that it has certain undesirable features which are needy of attention. The most glaring example is the constant violation by employers of section 77 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. A number of employers in Singapore still retain a colonial approach in industrial relations with their employees. They still think that labour should be docile and should not be organised. At the very first indication of attempts by workers to organise, these employers seek to destroy the workers' unity by wanton dismissal. The Industrial Relations Ordinance

Column: 217

provides specifically for penalties for such conduct. But today, for one reason or another, no employer has yet been prosecuted under section 77 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. It may be that the machinery for such prosecution is inadequate. It may be that the wording of section 77 makes it difficult for successful prosecution. But the Government should try to improve on the machinery of, or to amend, the Industrial Relations Ordinance to speedily mete out punishment to employers who flout the spirit of the Ordinance.

    This matter is of the utmost importance and urgency. We in the trade union movement have been co-operating with the Government in its policy of industrial peace with justice. The justice that is reposed in the industrial system, this justice we hope to find through the Courts. If the trade union movement finds that it cannot obtain this justice through the institutions of law, then it cannot be blamed if it seeks justice elsewhere.

    Over the past few years a number of employers appear to have escaped scot-free with their violation of the law. This violation has done no good to the employers themselves, to the trade union movement, and to society. I therefore call upon the Government to take urgent positive steps to rectify the situation which, if allowed to continue, will cause the very foundations of our democratic society to sink.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday the Member for Tampines described Mr Devan Nair and the N.T.U.C. as stooges of the P.A.P. Well, nobody could expect pro-Communist elements to make friendly remarks about those who have trounced them in the battle for the hearts and minds of the workers of Singapore. Workers do not support stooges, and this is the reason why the stooges of the Indonesian confrontationists daily continue to lose support from the workers of Singapore. Mr Devan Nair was once with the Communists, and he is not ashamed of the reason which led him to join them. But he is also not ashamed either of the reasons which led him to leave the Communist fold, for he discovered that far from fighting for the real

Column: 218

interests of the workers the Communists were only interested in exploiting them for anti-national political purposes. There is an honourable and a dishonourable way of breaking with your friends. Mr Nair did not crack up in prison and come out after making penitential statements. Unlike certain other persons, he never squealed to the police against his friends. But what Mr Devan Nair did is public knowledge. He openly and publicly took a stand against the Communists who betray the cause of Malayan socialism by acting as fifth columnists for foreign powers. The workers of Singapore know that had it not been for Mr Devan Nair's determined stand against the Communists, they would now have been prisoners of the friends of the Indonesian confrontationists. The workers of Singapore also know that Mr Nair has contributed more to trade unionism than all the Woodhulls, Puthuchearys and Lim Shee Pings put together. The Communists and their friends cannot be expected to understand the democratic concept of trade unionism which is the basis of the N.T.U.C. They cannot understand why the N.T.U.C. supports the Government on all fundamental, political and ideological issues. We are functionally independent of the Government. They cannot understand why it is possible for the postmen of Singapore to give full support to democracy and to Malaysia. It is also possible for the Singapore workers to take strike action against the Government. The N.T.U.C. supported the strike by the Public Daily Rated Employees Union in 1961 against the Government. It also supported the nurses and the police clerks when they went on strike. Recently employees of the Postal and Telecommunications Department went on strike and we were fully behind them. But all these thousands of workers are beyond the reach of the Communists simply because they know that the Government respects the democratic concept of trade unionism on which they are based. The Member for Tampines is too ignorant of democracy to appreciate that if the P.A.P. were an

Column: 219

anti-labour Government, then police clerks, for instance, would never have been able to go on strike. Does he believe, for instance, that in Communist countries police personnel would be allowed to go on strike? Does he even believe that his Indonesian friends would allow their police personnel to go on strike? However, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not my purpose to educate pro-Communists because they are beyond the reach of education. There is no more uneducable person than a Communist with a closed mind. We on this side of the House are more interested in educating the public of Singapore in the mechanics of democracy and in the fact that only in an open democratic society can the real freedom of the trade union movement be protected. I invite the Member for Tampines to look with unprejudiced eyes, if that is not beyond his capacity, at all our neighbouring territories, and I will give him a medal if he can show any country in South-East Asia which has labour legislation as advanced and as progressive as we have in Singapore. His real complaint is not that we have reactionary labour laws but that we do not love the Communists. We do not intend to betray the workers of Singapore by allowing them to be swallowed up by the fifth columnists of foreign powers. On that there will be no compromise.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me warn the pro-Communist elements in the trade union movement that we in the N.T.U.C. are out to succeed. We will expose them whenever and wherever they turn up their ugly faces. I can promise them that we regard it, in the words of Mr Khrushchev, as "our historical responsibility to bury them." This is inevitable and the Member for Tampines and others like him should appreciate the fact that it is historically inevitable that in Malaysia the proponents of an open democratic society will triumph over the Communists and their anti-national allies. They will not win as long as we are on this field because we will meet intelligence with greater intelligence; vigour and dedication with

Column: 220

greater vigour and dedication; determination with even greater determination. But it is time the Communists must realise that in dealing with us they are not dealing with reactionaries but with people who are dedicated to the ideal of a free, democratic non-Communist and socialist Malaysia.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, Indonesia's trade boycott has created an economic crisis of the first magnitude unprecedented in Singapore and it has overshadowed all our other problems. It is, therefore, on this issue, which surpasses all other issues, that is, on the consequence of Indonesia's economic confrontation, that I wish to take today's opportunity to draw the attention of the Government and of this Assembly. This is a problem to which the Government must give its full attention and seek a satisfactory solution.

    Since 22nd September a crippling stroke has gripped this island's economy and its 1.8 million people. Since the days of Stamford Raffles people can only gauge the influence of Indonesian trade on Singapore's economy. Even under the Japanese occupation trade never ceased to flow between Singapore and Indonesia. Now for the first time for many centuries there is a complete severance of trade between these two territories. The blow to Singapore's economy is indeed devastating. Whether we like it or not, the Singapore cow has been too dependent on Indonesia's pastures. The great wealth of Indonesia has for centuries, ceaselessly, effortlessly and unconsciously flowed through to Singapore, which is one of the greatest ports of the world. But on the 22nd of September this wealth stopped to flow. Singapore has no other pastures to turn to and is now experiencing a slow economic death. The question in the minds of the people is, will the great entrepot of Singapore be doomed forever? What will Singapore's future fortunes be? Since the great depression of 1929 to 1932, Singapore has never suffered in peace time a greater blow to her economy. There never has been a greater number of unemployed people, and this figure is steadily increasing. Traffic on

Column: 221

the Singapore River, which has been called the life-blood of Singapore's commerce and industry, has come to a standstill. Telok Ayer Street, the centre of high-level Indonesia trade, is almost deserted, except for unemployed stevedores and workers in dark blue Chinese uniforms squatting with silent faces cursing the Government, no money to drink even coffee and reminisce over the past. The merchants in the city are assessing their losses; their debts in Indonesia; their property confiscated; their future; their bank overdraft as 31st December approaches at a faster speed than usual. But, Sir, on these matters, they are unable to come to any definite conclusion. I do not wish to argue with the Government whether 8 per cent or 80 per cent of the business, or the people, or of the national income or the economy is affected; whether it is 8,000 people or 80,000 people who are unemployed as a result of Indonesian economic confrontation. This type of argument leads to no useful purpose.

    I wish to give a broad picture I have formed of the outcome of Indonesia's economic confrontation and put forward certain more constructive measures for Government's consideration. In the paramount interest of Singapore and for the salvation of our economy from complete wreck, let us use this Assembly to find a solution. Telok Ayer Street and the streets around it are the heart of Singapore's trade and commerce, particularly with Indonesia. The raw materials and goods that flow in and out of the Singapore River is the blood which flows through the main artery, the Singapore River, which feeds most of Singapore's population. Telok Ayer Street and the streets bordering it, together with the Singapore River, are a barometer of Singapore's prosperity. Now the twakows and the motor boats which used to shuttle in and out of the Singapore River have been left idle for nearly three months. If the Indonesia/Singapore trade relation is not normalised soon, these twakows will sink into the Singapore River one after the other from sheer inability to maintain them. The hundreds of ships on the Indonesian run are scattered throughout the whole

Column: 222

sea front. There has never been a greater conglomeration of ships in Singapore lying idle at any one time waiting for the tide and the barnacles to take its toll. If things do not improve, these ships would later be sold as scrap to meet the same fate as the Dutch ships which fled away from Indonesian confiscation and were anchored in Singapore several years ago. The Chinese tongkangs or sailing junks anchored at the mouth of the Kallang River are equally idle and as many in numbers.

    Sir, nobody can deny that trade and commerce in Singapore has been drastically curtailed, fatally hit. Nearly all businesses in Singapore are affected directly or indirectly by the interruption of trade with Indonesia.

    Singapore is the factory of Indonesia's raw materials and the warehouse of Indonesia's imports. Singapore's imports to and exports from the United Kingdom, the United States, Japan, Germany and other countries, in the overwhelming bulk, are only an extension of trade with Indonesia. If Indonesia does not ship her raw materials to Singapore to be processed and re-exported to the markets of the world from here, the value of exports to other foreign countries compiled by the Statistics Department would be correspondingly reduced. If Indonesia does not buy a substantial bulk of imports of textiles, food and other consumer goods from Singapore, the volume of imports of these commodities from the country of origin into Singapore would also be correspondingly reduced. The value of Indonesian trade cannot therefore be measured in terms of figures compiled by the Department of Statistics, because, Sir, Indonesian trade is unique. It is different from trade with Japan, the United States or the United Kingdom or any other foreign countries. Trade with these countries does not create employment in Singapore. If Japan refuses to sell us her radios and transistors, Singapore can buy them from other countries without making any difference to Singapore's national income or the level of employment. If any country refuses to buy rubber from Singapore, it can be sold to other countries. Trade with other

Column: 223

countries creates little employment in Singapore. Trade with Indonesia is, however, completely different. Indonesia not merely sends her raw materials to Singapore for re-exporting abroad, they are sent here for processing, grading, packing and in some cases manufactured into new products before re-export. Singapore is Indonesia's factory and Indonesia's warehouse. It is due to this fact that Indonesian trade has created so many jobs and such a huge volume of employment. It is not only the quantity but also the quality of Indonesian trade that requires our attention. In full recognition of the value of Indonesian trade towards maintaining Singapore's economy, Singapore cannot help but maintain friendly relationships with Indonesia. This is different from advocating merger with Indonesia. Singapore cannot afford enmity with all her neighbours, particularly with Indonesia. Indonesia is Singapore's number one exporter and importer. But, Sir, it is the multiplier effect of Indonesian trade that can either make Singapore prosperous or can destroy Singapore. One dollar of Indonesian trade creates far more employment than many tens of dollars of trade with other countries. One ton of Indonesian rubber imported can create jobs for tens of people in Singapore. Indonesian raw materials require so much processing, grading and repacking before being re-exported, and it is this which creates the jobs. Due to Singapore's competitive market, a stable currency, good banking and shipping facilities, foreign countries for centuries have preferred to buy Indonesian raw materials from Singapore at a slightly higher premium. It is difficult to assess the effect of severance of Indonesian trade on our national income. After taking into consideration the multiplier effect, and based on the figures compiled by the Statistics Department which are far below the real volume of Indonesian trade, it is safe to assume that Singapore's national income would drop by more than 50 per cent if economic confrontation were to continue for a year and if Government did not increase its public spending ---

Column: 224



    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Fifty?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: 50. Statistics compiled by Government are based on official Customs declarations. In the case of trade with foreign countries when there are normal foreign exchange conditions, the value of imports and exports in Customs declaration forms is fairly accurate. With Indonesia, however, the situation is different. Due to Indonesia's foreign exchange controls and the imposition of quotas on imports, the value of imports and exports declared to the Singapore Customs authorities is far below the real value. In addition, a substantial bulk of the trade with Indonesia never passes through the Customs. This odd situation has arisen because of the great difference between the official rate of exchange of the rupiah and its black market rate. Indonesian merchants exporting raw materials to Singapore, or for that matter any other foreign country, have to remit back to Indonesia the proceeds of the sale through the official rate of exchange. If they remit the full value back through the official exchange, they will lose heavily and no trade will follow. Indonesian exporters, therefore, must seek to reduce the value of their exports declared to the Indonesian authorities so that only the value declared has to be remitted back through the official exchange, and the balance of the proceeds could be sent back to Indonesia through the black market yielding many more rupiahs.

    In the case of imports, Indonesian merchants are required to obtain import quotas which are rather difficult to get. To enable import quotas, therefore, to go a longer way than the amount stated, Indonesian importers have to underestimate the value of their imports. This will also save them from the high import taxes. This under-estimation of import and export values on the part of Indonesian merchants is reflected in Singapore Customs declaration forms. Since Singapore is a free port the Singapore Customs are not particular about the value or the quantity of goods declared. In addition, the goods bought and sold via tongkangs by visitors from

Column: 225

Indonesia, the 1,000 runners who ply piece goods and luxury or semi-luxury goods between Singapore and Indonesia are seldom declared. It is therefore wrong to depend too much on statistics compiled from Customs forms as far as Indonesian trade is concerned. We should not be like ostriches, but must be prepared to face the consequence of economic confrontation boldly and to recognise that the Indonesian trade has been the cradle of Singapore's past prosperity. Singapore is now experiencing this economic blackout. It is no use comforting ourselves that Indonesia is suffering more than we do. Even if it were true, it is not going to help us. It offers us no consolation. Indonesia is basically an agrarian economy in which plenty of natural resources, trade and currency play a little part. Singapore with no land mass and hardly any natural resources depends solely on her entrepot trade. Cuba can stand the United States' economic confrontation, but Singapore, only a tiny island, cannot withstand Indonesia's economic confrontation.

    The situation is really very serious. The merchants who were promised a second New York and the laying of golden goose eggs in Singapore are now feeling frustrated and bitter. Many of them have lost heavily in the past two and a half months. Some firms have closed down and many more will close down on the 31st of December or near the Chinese New Year. Staff will be retrenched. These merchants cannot collect back their trading debts from businessmen in Indonesia. On the other hand, the banks here will soon be pressing them for the payment of their overdrafts. Many of them have had stocks, shops, ships, factories and properties in Indonesia confiscated or soon to be confiscated by the Indonesian authorities. Nearly 400 rubber mills and rubber smoking houses have been confiscated or will be confiscated. Thousands of millions of dollars of wealth will be gone. These merchants after years of hard work face economic damnation. And the promise of future wealth in

Column: 226

Jurong does not appeal to them because it cannot solve their immediate problems. As traders they are not experienced in industry. Many of them now do not want to invest their capital in any industry. They have little confidence that it is possible to industrialise Singapore unless Indonesian economic confrontation is settled.

    I am doubtful, Sir, whether the Government realises the gravity of the situation because the Government is repeating over and over again that the loss is only 8 per cent. There are few trades and occupations in Singapore not affected by Indonesia's economic boycott. It all depends on how long this confrontation lasts. In the last analysis, everybody will be affected. If confrontation lasts for a longer period even certain categories of Government employees will be affected because the Government will have no money to pay their salaries. Singapore being reduced to a mere skeleton of its prosperous past would not require so many civil servants. Singapore will not be the New York of Malaysia. Singapore would then become the expendable appendix of Malaysia. It is safe to say that six months after Indonesia's economic confrontation, 80 per cent of the people and 80 per cent of all trades, businesses and occupations will be affected. The effects of Indonesian economic boycott would surge forward like waves. Those who received instant effects were those on the 22nd of September - the twakow owners and the workers, the shipowners and the sailors, fishing boats fishing in Indonesian waters ---

    An hon. Member: Radio Jakarta.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: --- lorry owners, drivers and attendants and nearly a thousand runners who carry piece goods and luxury goods, the tongkangs carrying charcoal, firewood and timber logs, the thousands and thousands of waterfront workers and sundry labourers. These people were immediately affected on the 22nd of September. The next batch affected are

Column: 227

factory owners and the workers and traders with Indonesia. For the factory owners, the supply of all raw materials has stopped. Depending on how much stock is left the factories and the warehouses are now stopping work one after the other. For the traders, business stopped on the 22nd of September, 1963. It is only a matter of time that one after the other will close down and the staff retrenched. Indonesia's economic confrontation has hit Singapore's economy like a ton of bricks. The whole economy is now being paralysed. Promises of a prosperous Jurong will not help to remedy the situation. More positive action is required to neutralise the catastrophe.

    Sir, it is estimated that more than 30,000 people are already unemployed as a result of Indonesia's economic confrontation. The figure is increasing day by day. Many shops and firms will close down on the 31st of December. By Chinese New Year it will increase at an even faster rate. When this is added to the big pool of people already unemployed and the large number of students who are graduating from the secondary schools and the universities to find jobs, Singapore faces the biggest number of unemployed people in her history. It is far more difficult to estimate the number of people who will be indirectly affected by the Indonesian trade boycott. The biggest number of people unemployed in any trade as a result of confrontation comes from the rubber industry. The import of low-grade rubber from Indonesia gives jobs to nearly 10,000 workers directly engaged in processing, grading and packing, and indirect employment to many tens of thousands of people. Some rubber mills have closed down. Others are now working on the average of two days a week and when old stocks are finished, all will close down. Many allied firms, shops, closely dependent on the rubber industry will also have to close down.

    It is estimated that nearly 4,000 workers, mostly female workers, who

Column: 228

were engaged before confrontation in the grading of coffee beans imported from Indonesia, have lost their jobs.

    Nearly 1,000 workers in the sago factories will become jobless very soon. Some sago factories have closed down. Those with more stocks can survive for a few more weeks.

    More than 20 firms and nearly 2,000 workers in the rattan industry engaged in skin peeling and rattan curing are affected. When the rattan stocks are depleted, most of the workers will be thrown out of their jobs also. The Government has prohibited the export of raw rattan, but this is now circumvented by the import of low-quality Indonesian rattan via Hong Kong. Nearly 1,000 workers engaged in the gum and the damar grading industries have lost their jobs. Also more than 500 workers are thrown out of their employment in nutmeg grading.

    The charcoal trade is also severely hit. It is estimated that there are nearly 500 shops dealing in charcoal and firewood, with an average of three shop assistants each, and more than 1,000 workers engaged in the unloading of charcoal and firewood. There is estimated another 1,000 people engaged in tongkangs, transporting the charcoal and firewood from the Indonesian islands to Singapore. Although at present there are small sampans carrying charcoal and firewood coming to Singapore for the exchange of food, the quantities are negligible. The import of timber logs from Indonesia for Singapore sawmills is also a major trade. It has now completely stopped. Singapore also imports copra, copra cakes, pepper, tea, shells, chillies, beans and other raw materials from Indonesia which give work to thousands of workers. All this has now stopped.

    It is not only the importing firms and the factories or warehouses associated with Indonesian produce that are badly affected. The firms that export goods to Indonesia are also equally affected. Not only is there a loss in trade, but trade debts running into hundreds of

Column: 229

millions of dollars cannot be recovered. Singapore supplies Indonesia, particularly the Rhio Islands, Celebes, Sumatra and Borneo with foodstuffs, textiles, hardware and building materials, bicycles, second-hand cars and spare parts and all types of consumer goods. The main bulk of textiles imported to Singapore are re-exported to Indonesia. In addition, there are thousands of people employed in the garment industry situated in little shophouses making shirts, pyjamas, children's and ladies' wear, with Indonesia as their main market. It is difficult to estimate the number of workers engaged in the garment industry, in the making of embroidery, shoes, slippers, all types of piece goods with only Indonesia as the main market. The number of workers could run into tens of thousands. A large part of the work is sub-contracted to housewives and girls in their own homes. Most of the shops around New Market Street, Beach Road and Rochore Road, China Street areas, selling foodstuffs and vegetables to the Rhio Islands and Sumatra border regions have been badly affected. It is believed that a shopkeeper in Rochore Road committed suicide as a result of Indonesian economic confrontation. Unable to recover his debts from merchants in Indonesia and pressed by the creditors here, he chose suicide as an escape.

    The textile merchants in Circular Road, North Bridge Road, South Bridge Road and High Street are also badly affected. Indonesia is Singapore's biggest exporter of textiles. It has been the dumping ground for textiles, garment goods, shop-soiled goods and patterns not easily sold elsewhere. Textiles at present meant for Indonesian markets cannot be sold in any other place. Attempts to send them to Indonesia via Bangkok and Hongkong have not been successful. The Indonesian authorities have taken preventive measures against such moves. Many of the shops selling piece goods, medical products, watches, radios, pens, jewellery and all types of luxury or semi-luxury goods have Indonesia as the main market. There are nearly 1,000 runners in Singapore who make a comfortable living by bringing these goods in person into Indonesia.

Column: 230

Because Indonesia has a high import tax on this type of goods - and these are valuable goods - each ship or tongkang take a few runners attached to them whose main occupation is to buy these goods in Singapore and personally bring them over to Indonesia. These goods are seldom declared to the Customs. Now all these runners have lost their means of livelihood. Many of the shops selling piece goods and medical shops are badly affected. In turn, general importers of such goods from Hong Kong, Japan, Germany and the United Kingdom will be affected soon and the vicious circle will go on. Many of the factories in Singapore dependent on Indonesia as their main market, for instance, aerated water, biscuit and flour factories, and so on, will be affected. As production goes down, the owners and the workers in these factories will suffer.

    Another important sector in our economy badly hit is water and land transport and the waterfront workers. Several thousands of twakow and tongkang workers have been unemployed since 22nd September. The waterfront workers, the Harbour Board workers, the lorry-owners, drivers, attendants, many tens of thousands of labourers who depend on loading and unloading goods sent to and from Indonesia in twakows, motor boats, tongkangs, ships, warehouses, factories and firms are now unemployed or under-employed. Many fishing firms have closed down and many more will be closing down. The fishing boats are left to rot. Those engaged in fishing and the thousands of seamen in the hundreds of coasters on the Indonesian run are jobless. Most of the ships are now at anchor, and millions of dollars will be lost later due to barnacles. Some of the ships are sent to other Malaysian ports, to run at a heavy loss because it is considered more economical to keep them moving at a loss than to lose them because of barnacles and later sold as scrap.

    It is very hard to assess the total loss that Singapore has suffered after only 2½ months of economic confrontation. The Federation, except for Penang which has suffered an insignificant loss, has benefited economically as a result of Indonesia's trade boycott, because the

Column: 231

prices of tin, rubber, copra, timber and other primary produce have gone up mainly as a result of stoppage of such goods to the world markets.

    It is important for us to remember that the longer the Indonesian economic confrontation lasts, the harder it will be later for us to repair the damage and to recoup Singapore's entrepot trade.
